newsitem.title: LEBANON: Lebanon convicts 22 Israeli agents. [corrected 01:01 gmt 4/2]
newsitem.headline: Lebanon convicts 22 Israeli agents. [corrected 01:01 gmt 4/2]

text.p: Lebanon's military court on Monday sentenced 22 Lebanese men to up to 20 years in prison with hard labour for collaborating with Israel and planning attacks on Syrian forces.
Only four of the convicted were in custody. Kamil al-Rami, a former staff sergeant was sentenced to 10 years hard labour.

Abbas Dabja, who received 20 years, is a local official of the Syrian-backed Amal Movement, which launches guerrilla attacks against Israeli troops in Lebanon and is headed by Parliament Speaker Nabih Berri.

The indictment had stated that Abbas visited Israel and gave "detailed information on south Lebanon villages, Amal officials' homes, resistance centres, weapons depots and all those working for the resistance and the internal divisions of the Amal operation room".
The remaining two were sentenced to seven years in jail.

Fifteen (corrects from Fourteen) absentees were sentenced to 20 years hard labour. Those included Akel Hashem, western region commander of the South Lebanon Army (SLA), a 3,000-strong client militia which helps Israel control a border zone in south Lebanon. Two others were sentenced to 10 years.

Keitel al-Hayeh, a former major in the Lebanese army was sentenced to 12 years in jail. Hayek and two others were convicted with planning attacks that included a failed 1988 assassination attempt against Brigadier Ghazi Kenaan, head of the Syrian military intelligence in Lebanon.
Syria has 35,000 troops in the country and is Lebanon's main power broker.
Lebanon and Israel are still officially in a state of war despite over five years of peace talks which are currently stalled.
Under Lebanese laws, suspects convicted in absentia are retried when they surrender or get arrested.
